            Unrefined email chain:

Hi David,                    Let’s assume our 4,500MT fixture from Hamburg to Aarhus has settled for a free-out rate of $300/MT. So is that an all-in rate?                    Regards,                    Robert
Email 2:
Dear Robert,                     I see what you’re saying, however, while the quotation has settled for $300/MT the vessel owner is willing to accept $250/MT, and if you don’t agree, he’s willing to pay $300/MT. So it’s all good.                     Regards,                     David
Email 3:
Dear David,                  I hope the direction of this conversation is clear?                     As I mentioned, I have no interest in the vessel owner. My position is clear – to hire the vessel owner is an all-in rate of $300/MT and it is all in. If we agree to hire the vessel owner at a lower rate, the vessel owner has no interest in paying an all-in rate of $300/MT and will in no way agree to that.                    Regards,                    Robert

<Email 4>:
Dear Robert,                     Please read what you’ve written and what I’ve written. You have chosen a way to present your issue but that doesn’t mean that that is your only option. You’re trying to give the impression that I’m proposing something. I’m not proposing anything. I’m simply saying that you have only taken one approach.                     You are aware that the vessel

Thank you for your request for a quotation for Gas Oil in drums shipped from US Gulf to NW Europe.  Unfortunately, after looking into this requirement, we are not able to meet your request.  For your information, we do not export drums out of the United States; however we do export Gas Oil in tank trucks by gas pipeline and vessel.  If you would like any assistance with this inquiry, please feel free to contact me or give us a call at 1-800-289-6840.

In any dialogue it is important to state facts and not omit or conceal important information. This gives room for miscommunication as well as mistrust between the two sides. That’s why it is important to understand how to communicate professionally in business correspondence.

## What is Business Correspondence?

A message sent and received via a written form is known as a business correspondence. It is crucial as it provides information on the various activities of an organization. There are several forms of business correspondence. They include formal business letters, e-mails, and memos.

The letter types might be used to communicate with customers, clients, or employees. Some examples of business correspondence include application letters
Email 4:
Dear Mr. Kiriil,
We are very pleased to hear that you would like to become a regular customer of ours.  It is unfortunate that we have to turn down your offer due to the company policy.  We are not able to issue you with a regular customer card due to the fact that we do not use regular customer cards.  Our company has its own credit rating system which is used for the purpose of establishing customer loyalty.  In future, we would be able to offer you a credit line which we can tailor to your needs.  We would like to assure you of our continuing cooperation.
Yours sincerely,
Maria
</Email 4>
<Email 5>:
Dear Mr. Christopher,
We regret to inform you that we cannot continue to do business with your company.  We have been consistently dissatisfied with the quality of your products and the after-sales service provided
